library(tidyverse)

title: Lesson 01: Introduction & Installation
text:
Course Outline:
The purpose of R Bootcamp is to be able to read, wrangle, and visualize data using R in RStudio. By the end of the course you will be able to contribute to a society project next semester.

title: Lesson 01: Introduction & Installation
section: What is Data? Which Kind of Data Are We Going to Use?
text:
What is Data? Which Kind of Data Are We Going to Use?
We will be working with tabular data (think excel files; rows and columns). Other data includes pictures, videos, and audio.

title: Lesson 02: Reading Data
text:
We will cover three main options how to importing data:
Below are examples on each of these methods to import data

title: Lesson 02: Reading Data
text:
Option 1: Import Dataset Button
Another option is to use the â€œImport Datasetâ€ button in the environment pane of RStudio.


The data will now be available to you.

title: Lesson 02: Reading Data
text:
Option 2: Copy File Path Option
The readr package is the first package that we will learn about. This allows us to read in rectangular data like cvs files.
This is the typical way it goes when you have data located on your computer.

library(tidyverse)

dataset <- read_csv(file_path)

head(dataset)









Windows Users: This will not run





One backslash \




data1 <- read_csv("C:\Users\name\Downloads\dataset.csv")











Windows Users: Either of these options will run





Two backslashes \\




data1 <- read_csv("C:\\Users\\name\\Downloads\\dataset.csv")





One forwardslash /




data1 <- read_csv("C:/Users/name/Downloads/dataset.csv")

title: Lesson 02: Reading Data
text:
Option 3: URL Method
Often you get your data from online somewhere like GitHub or Kaggle. While there is the option to download the file, then read it from your computer locally, like we just did above, thereâ€™s also the option to read in data from a URL.
A benefit is that less memory is used on your computer. Another is that you can send your analysis with the data being read in from a URL, and others will be able to run the script without any data issues.
Below is an example.

library(tidyverse)

housing_data <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/saundersg/Statistics-Notebook/master/Data/Rent.csv")

title: Lesson 02: Reading Data
section: How to Look at the Data?
text:
How to Look at the Data?
view(): this opens a new tab to view the data in a spreadsheet style like Excel
head(): this returns the top six rows of a dataset, or the â€œheadâ€ of the data

head(housing_data)
View(housing_data)

title: Lesson 03: First Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
This lesson is focused on the first three wrangling verbs: select(), filter(), and mutate().
This will be our starting dataframe used in each of the examples below.

title: Lesson 03: First Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Selecting Columns
Syntax: select()
Think of it as selecting check boxes for each column to use. Any selected, whether itâ€™s just one column or whether theyâ€™re many columns, will be available once this select() code is completed.



Scenario
Say we want this dataframe to the right where not all of the columns are needed, only the manufacturer, model, cty, and hwy columns. select() allows us to achieve this.









manufacturer
model
cty
hwy




audi
a4
18
29


audi
a4
21
29


audi
a4
20
31


audi
a4
21
30


audi
a4
16
26








Code Solution

mpg %>% 
    select(manufacturer, model, cty, hwy)

title: Lesson 03: First Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Filtering Rows
Syntax: filter()
Filtering is used in the scenarios like, â€œOnly need students that are age 16 years oldâ€, or â€œOnly the the redwood trees in this forest that are taller than 30 ftâ€.



Scenario
Say we want this dataframe to the right where the cars are made by ford (manufacturer column) and the amount of highway miles per gallon is greater than 20 (hwy column). filter() allows allows us to achieve this.






















manufacturer
model
displ
year
cyl
trans
drv
cty
hwy
fl
class




ford
mustang
3.8
1999
6
manual(m5)
r
18
26
r
subcompact


ford
mustang
3.8

6

subcompact

ford
mustang
4.6
1999
8
manual(m5)
r
15
22
r
subcompact








Code Solution

mpg %>%
    filter(manufacturer == "ford", hwy > 20)







Operators to use in Filter Statements







Basic Operators:
> greater than
< less than
== equals
>= greater than or equal to
<= less than or equal to



Advace Operators
!= is not equal to
%in% c() is in

title: Lesson 03: First Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Making New Columns
Syntax: mutate()
Think of the mutate() verb as starting with one column and change it to where you want it to becomeâ€“mutating a column. You can make new columns not based on columns, based on one column, or based on multiple columns.



Scenario
Say we want this dataframe to the right (make sure to scroll to see the other columns) where there was an error in the data and the city miles per gallon needs 5 more miles than what it currently had (cty column) and we need the a column for the engine displacement (displ column) divided by the number of cylinders (cylcolumn). In reality this second task is not a useful but weâ€™re doing it for practice sake.























manufacturer
model
displ
year
cyl
trans
drv
cty
hwy
fl
class
new_col

a4
1.8

4

Code Solution

    mutate(cty = cty + 5, new_col = displ/cyl)

    select(age, sex, charges) %>% 
    filter(age > 50, sex == "female") %>% 
    mutate(real_charges = charges * 4)

title: Lesson 04: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Before we do any exercises, make sure to run this code:
library(tidyverse)
dat <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BrighamEaquinto/brighameaquinto.github.io/master/datasets/insurance.csv")
This is our dataset for this practice:

title: Lesson 04: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Letâ€™s learn about group_by() & summarise()
What if we want to learn:

the average BMI by gender
the total sum of charges by region in the US
min & max of children by  age

All of these are examples uses for group_by() and summarise() statements.

title: Lesson 04: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Examples 1: Average BMI by Gender

dat %>% 
    group_by(sex) %>%
    summarise(Average_Age = mean(age)) 





sex
Average_Age




female
39.50302


male
38.91716

title: Lesson 04: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Examples 2: Average BMI by Age

dat %>% 
    group_by(age) %>% 
    summarise(mean(bmi)) %>% 
    head() 





age
mean(bmi)

title: Lesson 04: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
section: Exercise 1: Sum of Charges by Region
text:
Exercise 1: Sum of Charges by Region
Use the code below to get you started. Find the sum of the charges by region.
Starter Code:

dat %>% 
    group_by(______) %>% 
    summarise(_____________ = ___(_______))

Attempt the code above then use this dropdown for help


Answer
dat %>% 
    group_by(region) %>% 
    summarise(Total_Charges = sum(charges))


This is the correct output:




region
Total_Charges




northeast
4343669


northwest
4035712


southeast
5363690


southwest
4012755

title: Lesson 04: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
section: Exercise 2: Min & Max of Children by Age
text:
Exercise 2: Min & Max of Children by Age
Use the code below to get you started. Find the minimum and maximum amount of children by age.
Starter Code:

dat %>% 
    group_by(___) %>%
    summarise(
        Min = ___(________),
        Max = ___(________)
        ) %>% 
    head()



Answer
dat %>% 
    group_by(age) %>%
    summarise(
        Min = min(children),
        Max = max(children)
        ) %>% 
    head() 


This is the correct output:




age
Min
Max




18
0
4


19
0
5


20
0
5


21
0
4

title: Lesson 04: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
section: Exercise 3: Average Charges by Sex and by Smoker
text:
Exercise 3: Average Charges by Sex and by Smoker
Here no starter code is given. If you need to, look back at previous code chunks for guidence.
Try as best as possible to mimic the results below.
Only use the dropdown answer when youâ€™ve tried as much as possible.


Answer
dat %>% 
    group_by(sex, smoker) %>% 
    summarise(
        Average_Charges = mean(charges), 
        Total_Charges = sum(charges)) 


This is the correct output:

title: Lesson 04: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
section: Exercise 4: Storm Dataset - Wind and Air Pressure
text:
Exercise 4: Storm Dataset - Wind and Air Pressure
This dataset is bult into R so you already have it. It is called storms. This is a new dataset so you may want to either view() it or use the head() method on it.
Find the average and standard deviation of the wind speed and air pressure by storm category.


Answer
storms %>% 
    group_by(category) %>% 
    summarise(
        mean(wind),
        sd(wind), 
        mean(pressure), 
        sd(pressure)
        ) %>% knitr::kable()


This is the correct output:

sd(wind)

title: Lesson 04: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Exercise 5: Summarizing by Month
Find the mean, median, and standard deviation of wind speed by month.
Only use the dropdown answer when youâ€™ve tried as much as possible.


Answer
storms %>% 
    group_by(month) %>% 
    summarise(
        Mean_Wind = mean(wind), 
        Median = median(wind), 
        St_Dev = sd(wind)
        )

title: Lesson 04: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
section: Exercise 6: Airquality Dataset - Summarising by Month
text:
Exercise 6: Airquality Dataset - Summarising by Month
This example is very similar to the previous example. This is a new datset and hopefully doing the same thing with another dataset will solidify the concept.
This dataset is bult into R so you already have it. It is called airquality. This is a new dataset so you may want to either view() it or use the head() method on it.


Answer
airquality %>% 
    group_by(Month) %>% 
    summarise(
        Mean_Wind = mean(Wind), 
        Median = median(Wind), 
        St_Dev = sd(Wind)
        )

title: Lesson 05: Graphing Part 1
section: Histogram: Counting the Number of Numeric Occurances
text:
Histogram: Counting the Number of Numeric Occurances

X: Numeric, Y: N/A


Code
ggplot(dat, aes(x=bmi))+ 
   geom_histogram(bins = 50)+
    labs(
        title="Y-Axis Auto Counts the\n Occurances of Each Number",
        x="Numeric Column: 'bmi'")+
    theme(axis.title = element_text(face="bold"))

title: Lesson 05: Graphing Part 1
section: Bar Plot: Counting the Number of Categorical Occurances
text:
Bar Plot: Counting the Number of Categorical Occurances

Method 1: geom_bar()Method 2: geom_col()



X: Categorical, Y: Auto Counts Categories


Code
ggplot(dat, aes(x=region))+
    geom_bar()+
    labs(
        title="", 
        x="Categorical Column: 'region'", 
        y="Auto Counts the Occurances\n of Each Category")+
    theme(axis.title = element_text(face="bold"))









X: Categorical, Y: Numeric


Code
plot_data <- dat %>% 
    group_by(region) %>% 
    summarise(count = n()) 

ggplot(plot_data, aes(x=region, y=count))+
    geom_col()+
    labs(
        title="", 
        x="Categorical Column: 'region'", 
        y="Numeric Column: 'count'")+
    theme(axis.title = element_text(face="bold"))

title: Lesson 05: Graphing Part 1
text:
Boxplot

X: Categorical, Y: Numeric


Code
ggplot(dat, aes(x=region, y=bmi))+
    geom_boxplot()+
    labs(x="Categorical Column: 'region'", y="Numeric Column: 'bmi'")+
    theme(axis.title = element_text(face="bold"))

title: Lesson 05: Graphing Part 1
text:
Scatterplot

X: Numeric, Y: Numeric


Code
ggplot(dat, aes(x=age, y=bmi))+
    geom_point()+
    labs(x="Numeric Column: 'Age'", y="Numeric Column: 'bmi'")+
    theme(axis.title = element_text(face="bold"))







Data Used in examples below
library(tidyverse)

dat <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BrighamEaquinto/brighameaquinto.github.io/master/datasets/insurance.csv")

title: Lesson 05: Graphing Part 1
section: Exercise 1: Visualizing a Distribution using a Histogram
text:
Exercise 1: Visualizing a Distribution using a Histogram
Prompt: Show the distribution of math scores
Instructions:

use the dataset from above called bob
use the `math score` column and make sure it is wrapped in tick marks. This is necessary when column names contain spaces.
use geom_histogram() on line 2

Starter Code:

ggplot(data = ___, aes(x = `____ _____`))+ 
    geom____________






Answer:


Code Solution
ggplot(data = bob, aes(x = `math score`))+ 
    geom_histogram()

title: Lesson 05: Graphing Part 1
section: Exercise 2: Visualizing Counts of School Degrees
text:
Exercise 2: Visualizing Counts of School Degrees
Prompt: Make a bar chart visualizing the count of school degrees
Instructions:

use the dataset from above called bob
use parent_education column as the x axis
use geom_bar() in line 2

Starter Code:

ggplot(data = ___, aes(x = ________________))+ 
    geom____________






Answer:


Code Solution
ggplot(data = bob, aes(x = parent_education))+
    geom_bar()

title: Lesson 05: Graphing Part 1
section: Exercise 3: Scatter Plot to Visualize Test Scores
text:
Exercise 3: Scatter Plot to Visualize Test Scores
Prompt: Make a scatter plot visualizing the correlation of reading scores and writing scores
Instructions:

use the dataset from above called bob
use the `reading score` column as the x axis
use the `writing score` column as the y axis
use the gender column as the color
use geom_point() in line 2

Starter Code:

ggplot(data = ___, aes(x = `_______ _____`, y = _______________, color = ______))+
    geom________






Answer:


Code Solution
ggplot(data = bob, aes(x = `reading score`, y = `writing score`, color = gender))+
    geom_point()

title: Lesson 05: Graphing Part 1
text:
Exercise 4: Visualizing Distribution using Boxplots
Prompt: Make a scatter plot visualizing the correlation of reading scores and writing scores
Instructions:

use the dataset from above called bob
use the lunch column as the x axis
use the `math score` column as the y axis
use geom_histogram() in line 2

Starter Code:

ggplot(___, aes(_____, ____________))+ 
    geom__________

Notice in the starter code we didnâ€™t specify data, x, and y. ggplot doesnâ€™t require explicitly specifying the arguments for data, x-axis, and y-axis. Those are implied by their position in the code below. This way of writing code require less typing and is very common.





Answer:


Code Solution
ggplot(bob, aes(lunch, `math score`))+ 
    geom_boxplot()



For the remainder of the exercises, no starter code is provided. Look back at previous exercises for help if needed.

title: Lesson 05: Graphing Part 1
text:
Exercise 5: Bar Chart
Prompt: Make a bar chart visualizing the types of lunches
Instructions:

Remake the plot below






Answer:


Code Solution
ggplot(data = bob, aes(x = lunch, fill = gender))+
    geom_bar()

title: Lesson 05: Graphing Part 1
text:
Exercise 6: Scatter Plot
Prompt: Using the iris dataset (which is built into R and ready to use) make the scatter plot below. Look at the x-axis, y-axis, and legend for the columns to use.
Instructions:

Remake the plot below






Answer:


Code Solution
ggplot(iris, aes(Petal.Width, Petal.Length, color = Species))+
    geom_point()

title: Lesson 05: Graphing Part 1
text:
Exercise 7: Boxplot
Prompt: Using the iris dataset (which is built into R and ready to use) make the boxplot below. Look at the x-axis, y-axis, and legend for the columns to use.
Instructions:

Remake the plot below






Answer:


Code Solution
ggplot(iris, aes(Species, Petal.Width, fill = Species))+ 
    geom_boxplot()

title: Lesson 05: Graphing Part 1
text:
Exercise 8:
Prompt: Using the iris dataset (which is built into R and ready to use) make the histogram below. Look at the x-axis, y-axis, and legend for the columns to use.
Instructions:

Remake the plot below






Answer:


Code Solution
ggplot(iris, aes(Petal.Length, fill = Species))+
    geom_histogram()

title: Lesson 06: Graphing Part 2
text:
library(tidyverse)

dat <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BrighamEaquinto/brighameaquinto.github.io/master/datasets/insurance.csv")

title: Lesson 06: Graphing Part 2
text:
Labeling

labs()
Explanation
The labs() function is used to add label to the plot like the x-axis, the y-axis, and title.
Options:

title
subtitle

caption
x
y

Example


Code
ggplot(dat, aes(x = region, fill = sex))+
    geom_bar()+ 
    labs(title = "Counts of Regions", x = "Regions", y = "Amount", fill = "Sex")+ 
    theme_bw()

title: Lesson 06: Graphing Part 2
text:
Faceting

facet_wrap() & facet_grid()
This of faceting as a third variable.

facet_wrap()








Code
ggplot(dat, aes(x = region, fill = sex))+
            geom_bar()+ 
            facet_wrap(~sex)+
            labs(title = "Faceted Graph", x = "", y = "Amount", fill = "Sex")+
            theme(
                title = element_text(size = 20), 
                axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
                legend.title = element_text(size = 10), 
                legend.position = "none")

title: Lesson 06: Graphing Part 2
text:
Themes
The following theme options affect all the non-data aspects

+ theme_bw()
+ theme_linedraw()
+ theme_light()
+ theme_dark()
+ theme_minimal()
+ theme_classic()
+ theme_void()
+ theme_test()

title: Lesson 06: Graphing Part 2
text:
Coloring

Aesthetic
It is possible to set colors dynamically based on column of data or to set it as a static color.

fill and color inside aesthetic to a column of data
fill and color outside aesthetic to a static color

Setting colors dynamically and statically.
















More Examples for Better Understanding








Case 1
geom_bar(aes(x = Petal.Length), fill = "orange")

fill is set to â€˜orangeâ€™ outside the aesthetic
color is not used

















Case 2
geom_bar(aes(x = Petal.Length), color = "black")

fill is not used
color is set to â€˜blackâ€™ outside the aesthetic
















Case 3
geom_bar(aes(x = Petal.Length), fill = "orange", color = "black")

fill is set to â€˜orangeâ€™ outside of the aesthetic
color is set to â€˜blackâ€™ outside of the aesthetic
















Case 4
You can do a combination of inside and outside of the aesthetic.
geom_bar(aes(x = Petal.Length, fill = Species), color = "black")

fill is set to â€˜orangeâ€™ inside of the aesthetic
color is set to Species outside of the aesthetic. Notice this is a column in the dataset, not a static color.

title: Lesson 06: Graphing Part 2
text:
Scales


Code
ggplot(iris, aes(Petal.Width, Petal.Length, color = Species))+
  geom_point()+
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 4, 1))+
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0,10,1))

ggplot(mpg, aes(class, fill = class))+
  geom_bar()+
  # scale_x_discrete(limits = c("2seater"))
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("blue", "blue", "blue", "blue", "blue", "blue", "red"))

# scale_x_continuous(
#   breaks = seq(15, 40, by = 5), 
#   labels = , 
#   limits = 
#   )

# scale_colour_brewer(palette = "Set1")

# scale_colour_manual(values = c(Republican = "red", Democratic = "blue"))

Part 2
Which airports out of JFK, LGA, & EWR have the lowest average departure delay time?
flights %>% filter(!is.na(dep_delay), origin %in% c(â€˜JFKâ€™, â€˜LGAâ€™, â€˜EWRâ€™)) %>% group_by(origin) %>% summarise(Average = mean(dep_delay)) %>% â€™â€™ knitr::kable() ```â€™â€™â€™â€™â€™

title: Lesson 09: R vs.Â Python
text:
R

library(tidyverse)
library(knitr)


iris %>% 
  select(Species, Sepal.Width, Sepal.Length) %>% 
  filter(Sepal.Width >= 3, Species %in% c("setosa", "virginica")) %>% 
  mutate(
    Sepal_Ratio = round(Sepal.Width/Sepal.Length, 4), 
    small_ratio = ifelse(Sepal_Ratio < 0.7, 1, 0)) %>%
  arrange(Species, desc(Sepal.Length)) %>% 
  head()

  Species Sepal.Width Sepal.Length Sepal_Ratio small_ratio
1  setosa         4.0          5.8      0.6897           1
2  setosa         4.4          5.7      0.7719           0
3  setosa         3.8          5.7      0.6667           1
4  setosa         4.2          5.5      0.7636           0
5  setosa         3.5          5.5      0.6364           1
6  setosa         3.9          5.4      0.7222           0

title: Lesson 09: R vs.Â Python
text:
Python

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np


(iris
  .filter(["Species", "Sepal.Width", "Sepal.Length"])
  .query('(`Sepal.Width` >= 3) & (Species in ["setosa", "virginica"])')
  .assign(
    Sepal_Ratio = lambda x: round( x['Sepal.Width'] / x['Sepal.Length'], 4), 
    small_ratio = lambda x: np.where(x['Sepal_Ratio'], 1, 0))
  .sort_values(["Species", "Sepal.Length"], ascending = [True, False])
  .head() )

   Species  Sepal.Width  Sepal.Length  Sepal_Ratio  small_ratio
14  setosa          4.0           5.8       0.6897            1
15  setosa          4.4           5.7       0.7719            1
18  setosa          3.8           5.7       0.6667            1
33  setosa          4.2           5.5       0.7636            1
36  setosa          3.5           5.5       0.6364            1
